Posts.Content: There are many cold cap therapies that those undergoing chemotherapy can use to prevent baldness. Some work better than others. Educate yourself because most doctors won't tell you about them. Most are not keeping up with these current technologies and don't care either way-cold cap use is not increasing their income. Search and you will find; Penguin cold caps, Elastogel caps, Digitana and Paxman. There is a whole topic on subject at thebreastcancer.orgweb site.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy doesn't have to equal Bald

Posts.Content: You DONT have to lose your hair! Cold caps are available that keep you from going bald. I have helped many women save their hair. Unfortunately doctors don't tell their patients about this technology. Read about the caps here http://penguincoldcap.net/ After you have your first treatment you'll find chemo isn't nearly as bad as you've imagined. It's the anxiety-fear of the unknown which is so stressful.
Posts.Title: Petrified of getting chemo

Posts.Content: There is a website devoted to this issue it's called taxotears. There is a 6-8% risk of permanent hair loss when taxotere is the chemo regimen. It's unfortunate the doctors gloss over that fact. Especially so when hair loss can be prevented entirely by using a cold cap during chemo. Penguin cold caps and Elastogel caps are what is available to the public.
Posts.Title: 2 years after chemo, my hair has not grown back

Posts.Content: I have applied for disability because of the chronic pain I have as a result of the axillary lymphnode dissection(ALND) a.k.a. lymphadectonomy and mastectomy(MX). It's been 3 years since my surgery. I've been denied social security disability twice and had 2 appeals. I'm still waiting for the result. Know that if you move forward that you're in for the long haul. My best recommendation would be for you to find 3 doctors who specialize in pain mgmt. Have them do a very detailed diagnosis/prognosis. Most pain mgmt. doctors don't care-they just want to provide with some meds and kick you out the door. Find one you believe will help you and continue to see him every 3-6 months to document that you have no progress in pain relief. Don't rely on a doctor provided by your insurnace. Pay out of pocket-it'll be worth every penny!
Posts.Title: Post mastectomy pain syndrome....disability???

Posts.Content: Scalp cooling with Penguin cold caps work. It's not as easy as it would be if there were a shampoo to use to save your hair, but they do work. I've seen many women save their hair using the caps. There is a whole forum topic on the breastcancer. org discussion board. It's under Cold Cap User's Past and Present to Save Their Hair.
Posts.Title: Help: don't want to loose my hair again

Posts.Content: I've had pain ever since my surgery 3 years ago. I believe it was caused by the axiallary lymphnode dissection. I couldn't even move my arm above my hip for 2 months. I did PT for 18 weeks and got better range of motion but I still have constant pain. From what I've read 50% of peole have chronis pain after mastectomy. I wish Dr.'s would acknowledge this becuase there are ways to prevent it.
Posts.Title: arm pain after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Have your freind go to the emergency room at a local hospital. Have her tell them she is in pain. That might speed things up a bit. Medi-CalÂ  approval can take some time, meanwhile she needs treatment. Los Angeles County has four county-run hospitals and partnerships with about 100 private clinics that care for indigent adults and other patients. Here is a link to a local Medi-Cal office in Hawthorne, CA http://dpss.lacounty.gov/dpss/offices/default.cfm?orgid=1157 You might want to go down there yourself and ask to speak to the supervisor. Ask them what your friend needs to provide to make this happen-now!This is another link to Health Care Services in LA http://dpss.lacounty.gov/dpss/health/wgyc/pdf_files/English% Look at pages 3 and 10. You should find some helpful info.
Posts.Title: HELP PLEASE!!!

Posts.Content: I have personally seen 30+ women save their hair using the Penguin Cold Caps. They do work! Unfortunately not all oncologists are sharing this information with their patients. Either because of their own lack of current knowledge or they believe they are the same caps that existed back in the 1980's and don't work. To learn more about the Penguin Cold Caps go to their website at msc-worldwide.com or go to breastcancer.org discussion's board and search under the topic 'Cold Cap Users Past and Present to Save Hair.'
Posts.Title: You don't have to lose your hair doing chemo!

Posts.Content: The only way to know for certain if it is cancer is to have a biopsy done. There are different types of biopsies. I think the one I had done was an ultrasound guided biopsy. They use a needle with a large hollow core to take a sample. The first time I had this done it didn't leave a scar. The last time it left broken capillariy veins that have never went away. I'd take your doctors suggestion and give it some time. It most likely will go away.
Posts.Title: lump doesn't show up on mammogram or ultrasound, do I need an excision biopsy?

Posts.Content: I can't believe no one on this board has heard of the hair sparring Penguin cold caps! They truly do work. I have helped many women with changing them during their chemo treatments. It saddens me to still find so many unknowing and needlessly suffering hair loss as a result of chemo. There is a thread on the breastcancer.org discussion board. Hundreds of women have used the caps and share tips and their experiences on there. Please spread the word so others don't have to suffer the same consequences.
Posts.Title: Scared about losing hair

Posts.Content: I've heard this happens too often. It's called neuropathy. I have heard of women taken L Glutamine to prevent this. It's best if taken in powder form. Many women put ice or frozen bags of peas on their fingernails and toenails while getting the taxotere or taxol infusion to prevent neuropathy and nail damage. Discussions on this and other important topics can be found on breastcancer.org on the discussion board.
Posts.Title: Nerve damage from Chemo

Posts.Content: I can't believe no one on this board has heard of the hair sparring Penguin cold caps! They truly do work. I have helped many women with changing them during their chemo treatments. It saddens me to still find so many unknowing and needlessly suffering hair loss as a result of chemo. There is a thread on the breastcancer.org discussion board. Hundreds of women have used the caps and share tips and their experiences on there. Please spread the word so others don't have to suffer the same consequences.
Posts.Title: Scared about losing hair

Posts.Content: What is Dr. Dellon going to do to remedy this? From what I've read the nerves can be damaged without any cutting done to them.

Posts.Content: I've heard this happens too often. It's called neuropathy. I have heard of women taken L Glutamine to prevent this. It's best if taken in powder form. Many women put ice or frozen bags of peas on their fingernails and toenails while getting the taxotere or taxol infusion to prevent neuropathy and nail damage. Posts.Title: Nerve damage from Chemo
